threat_actors.name: Unknown cybercriminal group (Matrix Push C2 operators)
threat_actors.title: Matrix Push C2 abuses browser notifications to deliver phishing and malware
threat_actors.original_title: Matrix Push C2 abuses browser notifications to deliver phishing and malware
threat_actors.content_snippet: Cybercriminals are using browser push notifications to deliver malware and phishing attacks. Researchers at BlackFog described how a new command-and-control platform, called Matrix Push C2, uses browser push notifications to reach potential victims. When we warned back in 2019 that browser push noti...
tactics: Abuse of browser push notification APIs
Social engineering via fake system‑like alerts
Real‑time victim monitoring through C2 dashboard
URL shortening to obscure malicious links
techniques: T1566.002 – Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment (malware payloads delivered via push)
T1071.001 – Application Layer Protocol: WebSockets (for real‑time client reporting)
T1105 – Ingress Tool Transfer (shortened URLs to deliver payloads)
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting via fake security alerts
procedures: Compromise or lure users into granting push‑notification permission
Use Matrix Push C2 panel to craft OS‑like notifications with trusted brand logos
Track which notifications are displayed and clicked in real time
Redirect clicked users to shortened malicious URLs that host phishing pages or malware loaders
victimology: Users of browsers that support push notifications (Chrome, Edge, Opera, Safari)
Individuals who accept notification prompts on compromised or malicious sites
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential large‑scale credential theft and financial loss, especially targeting cryptocurrency holders; high success rates due to trusted‑looking UI and real‑time monitoring.
mitigation_recommendations: Educate users to deny push‑notification requests from unknown sites
Enforce browser policies that block or require explicit admin approval for push notifications
Deploy web‑filtering solutions to block known malicious URL shortening domains
Monitor for unusual push‑notification subscription activity in endpoint telemetry
Implement multi‑factor authentication to mitigate credential theft impact
references: Malwarebytes – "Matrix Push C2 abuses browser notifications to deliver phishing and malware" (2025-11-24)
BlackFog research on Matrix Push C2 platform

threat_actors.title: Iberia discloses security incident tied to supplier breach
threat_actors.original_title: Iberia discloses security incident tied to supplier breach
threat_actors.content_snippet: Iberia warns customers of a supplier-related data breach as a threat actor claims to hold 77GB of stolen airline data. Iberia is warning customers about a data breach after a third-party supplier was hacked by a threat actor who claims to have stolen 77 GB of airline data. Iberia is the flag carrier...
techniques: T1195.001: Supply Chain Compromise - Compromise of third‑party supplier
T1567: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
T1588.006: Acquire Infrastructure for Sale of Stolen Data
T1499: Endpoint Denial of Service (used to distract during exfiltration, if applicable)
procedures: Compromise of external provider hosting airline‑related services
Collection of customer personal data (names, emails, loyalty IDs)
Extraction of technical documents (aircraft maintenance, engine data, ISO 27001/ITAR files)
Packaging of ~77 GB of data for sale on underground forums
Threat actor communication via social media (Twitter) to advertise data
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Exposure of personal identifiers for airline customers and sensitive aircraft maintenance data; potential competitive advantage for state actors; financial loss risk if data is used for fraud or sold to adversaries.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict vendor risk management and continuous monitoring of third‑party access.
Enforce zero‑trust network segmentation for supplier connections.
Require multi‑factor authentication for all privileged accounts, including supplier accounts.
Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit.
Conduct regular security assessments and penetration testing of supply‑chain partners.
Deploy data loss prevention (DLP) solutions to detect large exfiltration volumes.
Monitor dark‑web forums for leaked data and threat actor chatter.

threat_actors.name: APT24
threat_actors.title: BadAudio malware: how APT24 scaled its cyberespionage through supply chain attacks
threat_actors.original_title: BadAudio malware: how APT24 scaled its cyberespionage through supply chain attacks
threat_actors.content_snippet: APT24 used supply chain attacks and varied techniques to deploy the BadAudio malware in a long-running cyberespionage campaign. China-linked group APT24 used supply-chain attacks and multiple techniques over three years to deploy the BadAudio downloader and additional malware payloads, Google Threat...
tools: Google Threat Intelligence Group analysis tools
techniques: T1041 Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attack_patterns: Supply chain compromise of a Taiwanese digital marketing firm
Web compromise with malicious JavaScript injection
DLL hijacking and sideloading to achieve execution
In‑memory decryption and execution of second‑stage payloads
procedures: Inject malicious JavaScript into compromised websites
Modify JS/JSON files on compromised marketing firm assets
Deploy BadAudio downloader as a malicious DLL
Encrypt payloads with hard‑coded AES key
Transmit host information inside HTTP cookie values
Decrypt and execute Cobalt Strike Beacon in memory
Persist via BAT, VBS, and LNK scripts that place the DLL and trigger sideloading
Use encrypted archives to hide malicious components
threat_actors.impact_assessment: A multi‑year espionage operation that compromised over 1,000 domains, established persistent footholds on Windows systems, and enabled the deployment of Cobalt Strike beacons for further post‑compromise activity, resulting in potential exfiltration of sensitive geopolitical and commercial data.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict supply‑chain security controls and code‑signing verification for third‑party software.
Monitor and block unknown or unsigned DLLs loaded by legitimate executables.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting in‑memory execution and control‑flow flattening.
Enforce network monitoring for anomalous cookie‑based C2 traffic and encrypted outbound connections to known BadAudio C2 infrastructure.
Apply multi‑factor authentication and phishing awareness training to reduce spear‑phishing success.
Regularly scan web assets for malicious JavaScript injections and compromised third‑party scripts.
Use threat‑intel feeds to block known BadAudio domains and associated IP addresses.
Segment networks to limit lateral movement from compromised hosts.
Maintain up‑to‑date patching of all software, especially web frameworks and content‑management systems.
references: SecurityAffairs article: BadAudio malware: how APT24 scaled its cyberespionage through supply chain attacks (2025-11-22)
Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) report on BadAudio

threat_actors.name: ToddyCat
threat_actors.title: ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1
threat_actors.original_title: ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction Email remains the main means of business correspondence at organizations. It can be set up either using on-premises infrastructure (for example, by deploying Microsoft Exchange Server) or through cloud mail services such as Microsoft 365 or Gmail. At first glance, it might seem that usi...
primary_objectives: obtain covert access to corporate email communications
steal browser credentials and session tokens
techniques: T1567.001 Exfiltration Over Web Services (OAuth tokens)
T1078 Valid Accounts (privileged domain controller access)
attack_patterns: Use of legitimate admin tools for evasion
procedures: Deploy TomBerBil PowerShell variant on domain controllers via scheduled task
Use SMB (c$) to enumerate user profiles and copy Chrome, Edge, Firefox databases and DPAPI master keys
Encrypt copied files with DPAPI and exfiltrate via internal network
Use custom TCSectorCopy utility to block‑by‑block copy locked Outlook OST files
Parse OST files with XstReader/XstExport to extract email content
Dump memory of Microsoft 365 client processes (Outlook, Teams, etc.) with SharpTokenFinder or ProcDump to harvest JWT access tokens
Compress dumps with WinRAR and transfer to external C2 via SMB
Clean up artifacts and maintain persistence through scheduled tasks
victimology: Enterprises with on‑premises Exchange or Microsoft 365 deployments
Organizations where attackers have obtained privileged domain‑controller access
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Successful theft of email communications, credentials, and authentication tokens enables long‑term espionage, credential reuse, and potential further compromise of cloud services. Data breach severity ranges from moderate to high depending on the sensitivity of the exfiltrated correspondence.
mitigation_recommendations: Enable detailed auditing for access to browser profile directories and DPAPI key folders; monitor EventID 5145 for SMB accesses
Restrict SMB admin shares (c$) and limit privileged lateral movement
Monitor creation and execution of scheduled tasks that launch PowerShell with -exec bypass
Deploy EDR/EDR solutions to detect abnormal PowerShell scripts and process memory dumping (ProcDump, MiniDumpWriteDump)
Enforce MFA and conditional access for Microsoft 365 accounts; regularly rotate OAuth refresh tokens
Apply file‑level protection on Outlook OST files and audit access (EventID 4663) with exclusions for legitimate Outlook processes
Block or tightly control the use of third‑party utilities such as TCSectorCopy and SharpTokenFinder
Implement least‑privilege principles for domain‑controller accounts and isolate admin workstations
Regularly review and purge unused credentials stored in browsers; use browser hardening policies
references: Securelist article "ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1" (2025‑11‑21)
Kaspersky Threat Intelligence reports on ToddyCat

threat_actors.title: Sturnus: New Android banking trojan targets WhatsApp, Telegram, and Signal
threat_actors.original_title: Sturnus: New Android banking trojan targets WhatsApp, Telegram, and Signal
threat_actors.content_snippet: The Android trojan Sturnus targets communications from secure messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram and Signal. Sturnus is a new Android banking trojan with full device-takeover abilities. It bypasses encrypted messaging by capturing on-screen content and can steal banking credentials, remotely con...
techniques: Accessibility Service abuse to capture UI‑tree events
Fallback screenshot reconstruction from Accessibility events
VNC RFB protocol for remote screen streaming
AES‑256/CBC encryption with RSA key exchange
Device admin rights abuse to prevent removal
Sensor and hardware profiling for evasion
procedures: Register device via HTTP POST, receive UUID and RSA key
Generate local AES‑256 key, encrypt with RSA, store Base64
Capture on‑screen content of WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal
Log text changes, clicks, focus shifts via Accessibility Service
Send captured data to C2 server
Maintain persistence through Device Administrator rights
Monitor SIM swaps, rooting attempts, developer settings
victimology: Users of encrypted messaging apps (WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal) in Southern and Central Europe
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High impact: enables theft of banking credentials, exposure of private communications, and full remote control of victim devices, leading to potential financial loss and privacy breaches.
mitigation_recommendations: Install apps only from trusted sources (Google Play Store).
Keep Android OS and security patches up to date.
Review and restrict Accessibility Service permissions; disable for unknown apps.
Use mobile security solutions that detect overlay phishing and suspicious behavior.
Monitor device administrator privileges and revoke unnecessary ones.
Educate users about phishing overlays and the risks of granting extensive permissions.
Employ network monitoring to detect anomalous HTTP POST registrations to unknown C2 domains.

threat_actors.name: koneko
threat_actors.title: Blockchain and Node.js abused by Tsundere: an emerging botnet
threat_actors.original_title: Blockchain and Node.js abused by Tsundere: an emerging botnet
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction Tsundere is a new botnet, discovered by our Kaspersky GReAT around mid-2025. We have correlated this threat with previous reports from October 2024 that reveal code similarities, as well as the use of the same C2 retrieval method and wallet. In that instance, the threat actor created ma...
primary_objectives: sell malicious builds on a marketplace
tactics: Supply chain compromise via npm typosquatting
Malicious MSI installers disguised as game installers
Use of Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) tools for delivery
Persistence via pm2 and Registry Run keys
attack_patterns: Supply chain attack via npm typosquatting
procedures: Typosquatting of popular npm packages (e.g., Puppeteer, Bignum.js)
Distribution of malicious MSI installers that embed Node.js binaries
PowerShell script that downloads official Node.js zip, extracts to %LOCALAPPDATA%\NodeJS
Installation of npm packages ws, ethers, pm2 to enable networking, blockchain interaction, and persistence
AES‑256‑CBC encryption of loader and configuration files
Fetching C2 WebSocket URL from an Ethereum smart contract using ethers library
Dynamic evaluation of JavaScript commands received from C2
Creation of bot builds via a public marketplace panel and linking builds to user IDs
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The botnet provides a resilient, monetizable platform for proxy services, cryptocurrency theft/mining, and potential distribution of additional payloads. Its use of blockchain C2 makes takedown difficult, and the public marketplace lowers the barrier for other threat actors, increasing overall risk to a wide range of victims.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict package verification for npm (use signed packages, lockfile integrity checks)
Monitor and block unknown MSI installers, especially those masquerading as game installers
Enforce application whitelisting for Node.js binaries and PowerShell scripts
Detect and alert on creation/modification of Registry Run keys pointing to %LOCALAPPDATA%\NodeJS
Network monitoring for outbound WebSocket connections to suspicious IPs/ports
Detect anomalous traffic to Ethereum RPC endpoints and smart contract queries
Educate users about phishing lures related to popular games and piracy sites
Restrict use of RMM tools to authorized personnel and monitor their activity
Deploy endpoint detection that can identify obfuscated JavaScript and AES‑encrypted payloads
Regularly audit installed npm packages for unexpected or malicious modules
references: Securelist article: "Blockchain and Node.js abused by Tsundere: an emerging botnet" (2025-11-20)

threat_actors.title: Attackers are using “Sneaky 2FA” to create fake sign-in windows that look real
threat_actors.original_title: Attackers are using “Sneaky 2FA” to create fake sign-in windows that look real
threat_actors.content_snippet: Attackers have a new trick to steal your username and password: fake browser pop-ups that look exactly like real sign-in windows. These “Browser-in-the-Browser” attacks can fool almost anyone, but a password manager and a few simple habits can keep you safe. Phishing attacks continue to evolve, and ...
tactics: Targeted redirection of non‑targets to benign sites
techniques: T1059.007 Command and Scripting Interpreter: JavaScript
T1564.001 Hide Artifacts: Fast Flux DNS
procedures: Deploy obfuscated HTML/CSS code that renders a fake address bar and login form within a web page
Adapt the fake window UI to the victim’s OS and browser fingerprint
Serve the malicious page only to high‑value targets while redirecting other visitors
Rotate short‑lived domains to evade blocklists
victimology: Internet users who click unsolicited links
High‑value individuals or employees with privileged access
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential large‑scale credential theft leading to account compromise, financial loss, and further lateral movement within victim organizations.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce use of reputable password managers that auto‑fill only on legitimate login forms
Require multi‑factor authentication (MFA) for all privileged accounts
Deploy anti‑phishing browser extensions (e.g., Malwarebytes Browser Guard) with heuristic detection
Educate users to verify URLs by hovering over links and to avoid entering credentials on pop‑up windows
Implement DNS filtering and blocklists that can handle fast‑flux domains
Monitor for anomalous credential usage and implement credential‑based threat detection
references: Malwarebytes article: "Attackers are using “Sneaky 2FA” to create fake sign-in windows that look real" (2025-11-19)

Provide the kit as a Phishing‑as‑a‑Service platform for low‑skill actors

threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential large‑scale credential compromise leading to account takeover, financial loss, and lateral movement within victim networks.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement phishing‑resistant MFA methods (e.g., hardware security keys, FIDO2)
Educate users about browser‑in‑the‑browser attacks and address‑bar spoofing
Deploy anti‑phishing email gateways and URL filtering
Enforce strict content security policies on corporate web applications
Monitor for anomalous login attempts and token usage

threat_actors.original_title: Dutch police takes down bulletproof hosting hub linked to 80+ cybercrime cases
threat_actors.content_snippet: Dutch police seized 250 servers running a bulletproof hosting service tied to cybercriminals and linked to over 80 investigations since 2022. Dutch police Politie, seized 250 servers running an unnamed bulletproof hosting service used solely by cybercriminals. Active since 2022, it appeared in over ...
primary_objectives: Enable malicious infrastructure for ransomware, phishing, botnets, and extortion
Monetize hosting services through subscription fees
tactics: Offer bulletproof hosting that ignores abuse reports
Operate in jurisdictions with weak enforcement
Use Telegram channels for promotion and customer support
Frequent relocation of servers to evade detection
techniques: Use of compromised infrastructure for C2
procedures: Advertise services on underground forums and Telegram
Provide payment via cryptocurrency
Delete Telegram posts and migrate to new channels when under pressure
Potential exit‑scam behavior when services are seized
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High – the service underpinned more than 80 cybercrime investigations across multiple sectors, facilitating ransomware, phishing, botnet, and extortion operations worldwide.
mitigation_recommendations: Block known IP ranges and domains associated with CrazyRDP in firewalls and DNS filters
Monitor for traffic to anonymous VPS/RDP services, especially from high‑risk geographies
Implement threat intel feeds that flag bulletproof hosting providers
Enforce strict egress filtering to prevent unauthorized C2 communications
Educate users about phishing and ransomware tactics that often rely on such hosting

threat_actors.name: Contagious Interview
threat_actors.title: North Korean threat actors use JSON sites to deliver malware via trojanized code
threat_actors.original_title: North Korean threat actors use JSON sites to deliver malware via trojanized code
threat_actors.content_snippet: North Korean Contagious Interview actors now host malware on JSON storage sites to deliver trojanized code projects, NVISO reports. North Korea-linked actors behind the Contagious Interview campaign have updated their tactics, using JSON storage services (e.g. JSON Keeper, JSONsilo, and npoint.io) t...
primary_objectives: Steal credentials and crypto wallet information
tactics: Spearphishing via fake recruiter profiles on LinkedIn
Delivery of trojanized demo projects in code repositories
Use of legitimate JSON storage services to host payloads
Obfuscation of payload URLs via Base64-encoded API keys
Ingress tool transfer from public paste sites
procedures: Create a fake recruiter LinkedIn profile
Offer a job interview that includes a demo project repository
Embed a hidden file with a Base64‑encoded API key pointing to a JSON storage URL
Host the next‑stage malware (e.g., BeaverTail) on JSON Keeper, JSONsilo, or npoint.io
Use Pastebin to deliver auxiliary tools such as TsunamiKit
Deploy the InvisibleFerret RAT to maintain persistence
known_iocs: JSON storage URLs on jsonkeeper.com, jsonsilo.com, npoint.io
Pastebin URLs used for TsunamiKit delivery (e.g., pastebin.com/u/NotingRobe2871_FranzStill8494)
GitHub/GitLab repositories hosting trojanized demo projects
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Compromise of developer workstations, theft of cryptocurrency wallet credentials, exfiltration of source code and personal data, and establishment of persistent remote access capabilities.
mitigation_recommendations: Do not execute code from unknown or unsolicited repositories, especially those received via recruiter contacts.
Verify recruiter identities through official company channels before accepting interview materials.
Implement strict code review processes; scan all incoming code for hidden files, Base64 strings, and external URLs.
Block known malicious JSON storage domains and monitor outbound traffic to such services.
Use sandbox environments to analyze demo projects before execution.
Enable multi‑factor authentication for developer accounts and crypto wallets.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting BeaverTail, OtterCookie, and InvisibleFerret behaviors.
references: SecurityAffairs article "North Korean threat actors use JSON sites to deliver malware via trojanized code" (2025-11-17)

threat_actors.name: Lighthouse Operators
threat_actors.title: Google Sues to Disrupt Chinese SMS Phishing Triad
threat_actors.original_title: Google Sues to Disrupt Chinese SMS Phishing Triad
threat_actors.content_snippet: Google is suing more than two dozen unnamed individuals allegedly involved in peddling a popular China-based mobile phishing service that helps scammers impersonate hundreds of trusted brands, blast out text message lures, and convert phished payment card data into mobile wallets from Apple and Goog...
primary_objectives: Enroll stolen cards into mobile wallets (Apple Pay, Google Pay)
tools: SMS sending platforms / bulk SMS gateways
Phone panel for real‑time OTP handling
tactics: Use of Telegram and YouTube for support and recruitment
Collaboration between developer, data broker, spammer, theft, and admin groups
Mass‑sending of spoofed messages via compromised SMS gateways
techniques: Brand impersonation (USPS, toll roads, e‑commerce sites, banks, brokerage firms)
One‑time code harvesting to bypass OTP verification
Use of stolen credit cards to purchase Google Ads for malicious site promotion
Live operator panels to process time‑sensitive OTPs
procedures: Acquire target phone numbers from data broker lists
Send spoofed SMS with lure linking to phishing site
Collect card details on templated checkout page
Trigger mobile‑wallet enrollment request to victim’s bank
Capture OTP from victim and complete enrollment
Load multiple wallets onto a single device, wait 7‑10 days, then cash out or sell device
victimology: Individuals receiving USPS or toll‑road notices
Users of Apple Pay or Google Pay
known_iocs: Rotating phishing domains (estimated 25,000 active per 8‑day window)
Telegram groups associated with Lighthouse support
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 1 million victims in more than 120 countries; large-scale financial loss from fraudulent card charges and resale of compromised mobile wallets; significant reputational damage to targeted brands.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement SMS filtering and carrier‑level anti‑spoofing controls
Educate users to verify sender numbers and avoid clicking links in unsolicited texts
Deploy mobile‑wallet enrollment verification that does not rely solely on OTPs
Monitor and block known phishing domains and ASNs (Tencent, Alibaba) associated with smishing
Enforce strict domain registration monitoring for brand‑lookalike domains
Use threat‑intel feeds to block Telegram channels linked to Lighthouse
Apply transaction monitoring for rapid wallet enrollment activity
Encourage banks to flag enrollment requests originating from suspicious IPs or devices
references: Krebsonsecurity – Google Sues to Disrupt Chinese SMS Phishing Triad (2025‑11‑13)
Silent Push – May 2025 Smishing Triad report
Google lawsuit filing (Southern District of New York, 2025‑11‑12)

threat_actors.name: XWorm Malware-as-a-Service Operators
threat_actors.title: We opened a fake invoice and fell down a retro XWorm-shaped wormhole
threat_actors.original_title: We opened a fake invoice and fell down a retro XWorm-shaped wormhole
threat_actors.content_snippet: Somebody forwarded an “invoice” email and asked me to check the attachment because it looked suspicious. Good instinct—it was, and what we found inside was a surprisingly old trick hiding a modern threat. What it does If the recipient had opened the attached Visual Basic Script (.vbs) file, it would...
tactics: Use of obsolete script types (VBS) to evade modern filters
Multi-stage payload delivery (VBS → BAT → PowerShell → fileless execution)
Obfuscation and padding to hinder analysis
In‑memory execution to avoid disk artifacts
techniques: T1547 – Boot or Logon Autostart Execution (copy to %USERPROFILE%)
procedures: Send invoice‑style email with .vbs attachment named to look like a PDF
VBS drops a BAT file in %TEMP% and invokes it via WMI
BAT copies itself to user profile as aoc.bat and launches a hidden PowerShell loader
PowerShell decodes Base64 payload, decrypts AES‑encrypted data, decompresses GZip, and loads malicious executables in memory
Backdoor.XWorm establishes C2 channel for data exfiltration and remote commands
victimology: Organizations that process invoices or payments
SMBs with limited email security controls
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Successful execution can lead to full system compromise, theft of sensitive business data and credentials, potential ransomware infection, and lateral movement within the victim network.
mitigation_recommendations: Block .vbs, .bat, and other script extensions at the mail gateway
Enforce strict attachment scanning and sandboxing
User security awareness training focusing on invoice‑type phishing
Disable execution of scripts from email clients
Implement application whitelisting on endpoints
Deploy EDR solutions capable of detecting fileless PowerShell activity
Monitor for known mutexes (e.g., 5wyy00gGpG6LF3m6) and anomalous process creation
Restrict write permissions to %TEMP% and user profile directories for non‑privileged accounts
references: Malwarebytes Blog – "We opened a fake invoice and fell down a retro XWorm‑shaped wormhole" (2025‑11‑13)
MITRE ATT&CK – XWorm (Txxxx identifiers as applicable)

tools: Custom phishing kit with Vercel hosting (xxx-three-theta.vercel.app)
techniques: Use of base64‑encoded parameters in URLs (T1027.001)
WebSocket communication for real‑time data exfiltration (T1021.004)
procedures: Send email appearing to be an internal "Email Delivery Report" with a "Move to Inbox" button
Include an "Unsubscribe" link that redirects through cbssports.com to the phishing landing page
Landing page hosts a fake login form pre‑filled with the victim's domain
Credentials captured via a persistent WebSocket channel
Obfuscate page code to evade static analysis
victimology: Corporate employees receiving internal email notifications
Users of enterprise email and cloud storage platforms
campaigns: Secure Message System Upgrade Phishing Campaign

mitigation_recommendations: Implement robust email authentication (DMARC, SPF, DKIM)

Enforce MFA on all email and cloud accounts

threat_actors.original_title: Google sounds alarm on self-modifying AI malware
threat_actors.content_snippet: Google warns malware now uses AI to mutate, adapt, and collect data during execution, boosting evasion and persistence. Google’s Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) warn of a new generation of malware that is using AI during execution to mutate, adapt, and collect data in real time, helping it evade de...
tools: Standard APT28 toolset (X-Agent, Fancy Bear implants)
attack_patterns: Self‑modifying malware via LLM feedback loops
procedures: Query LLM APIs (Gemini, Hugging Face) to generate obfuscated VBScript or Windows commands at runtime
Store regenerated malicious code in Startup folder for persistence
Use compiled Python binaries (PyInstaller) to embed LLM query logic
Exfiltrate collected files to attacker‑controlled servers or public GitHub repositories
Leverage stolen API tokens to access generative AI services
victimology: Entities with valuable geopolitical or strategic data
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High impact due to novel AI‑driven capabilities that enable real‑time evasion, self‑modification, and automated data collection, increasing detection difficulty and broadening the attack surface.
mitigation_recommendations: Block outbound traffic to known LLM provider endpoints unless explicitly required
Monitor for anomalous API calls to Gemini, Hugging Face, or other generative AI services
Implement strict API key management and rotate credentials regularly
Deploy behavior‑based detection that flags dynamic code generation or self‑modifying scripts
Enforce least‑privilege execution for PowerShell, VBScript, and Python processes
Network segmentation to isolate systems that interact with external AI services
Regularly audit startup locations and scheduled tasks for unknown scripts
Educate users on spear‑phishing techniques and AI‑generated lure detection
references: SecurityAffairs article "Google sounds alarm on self-modifying AI malware" (2025-11-06)

tools: Card‑emulating devices (e.g., modified smartphones, smartwatches, custom hardware)
tactics: use of card‑emulating hardware at ATMs
techniques: T1059 Command and Scripting Interpreter (malicious app installer)

Send captured data to attacker‑controlled server in real time

threat_actors.content_snippet: A Ukrainian man indicted in 2012 for conspiring with a prolific hacking group to steal tens of millions of dollars from U.S. businesses was arrested in Italy and is now in custody in the United States, KrebsOnSecurity has learned. Sources close to the investigation say Yuriy Igorevich Rybtsov, a 41-...
primary_objectives: Launder stolen funds via wire transfers
tools: Jabber IM for C2 and alerts
malware_families: Dridex (used by later Evil Corp operations)
tactics: Back‑connect proxy using victim’s infected PC
Use of Jabber instant messaging for real‑time alerts
Payroll manipulation to create mule accounts
techniques: Money mule recruitment via work‑at‑home schemes
procedures: Deploy custom Zeus variant (Jabber Zeus) to victim endpoints
Monitor victim activity; when OTP entered, send Jabber alert (Leprechaun)
Rewrite victim browser HTML to capture multi‑factor authentication codes
Relay banking sessions through victim IP address
Modify payroll systems to add mule accounts
Transfer stolen funds through layered mule networks in Ukraine and the UK
victimology: Small to mid‑size enterprises with payroll processing
Companies handling online banking with MFA
U.S. businesses targeted for financial theft
known_iocs: Jabber IM usernames associated with group members (e.g., MrICQ)
Custom Zeus binary hashes (e.g., SHA‑256: d4c3... )
C2 domains observed in indictment documents
Known money mule bank account numbers used in wire transfers
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The group stole tens of millions of dollars from U.S. businesses, leading to over $73 million in restitution orders and widespread financial loss for dozens of small‑to‑mid‑size companies.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement hardware‑based multi‑factor authentication that is resistant to interception
Enforce strict transaction monitoring and anomaly detection for payroll and wire transfers
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting Zeus‑family malware
Conduct regular phishing awareness training for employees
Segment networks to isolate financial systems from general user workstations
Monitor Jabber/XMPP traffic for suspicious C2 activity
Maintain up‑to‑date threat intelligence feeds for known Zeus variants and money mule indicators

tactics: Use of Accessibility Service for overlay attacks
Human‑like typing delays to evade behavioral detection
techniques: T1055 – Process injection via dynamic module loading (Brokewell code)
T1547 – Boot or Logon Autostart Execution (dropper installation)
T1053 – Scheduled/automated actions with random delays
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting from banking and crypto apps
procedures: Dropper installs malicious APK and prompts user to enable Accessibility
Overlay screen hides permission request and mimics loading UI
Operator panel provides "Delayed text" option for human‑like input
MQTT protocol used for C2 communication with domains under google-firebase.digital
Dynamic decryption of native strings and loading of a limited Brokewell module for UI interaction
victimology: Android users of banking apps in Italy and Brazil
General Android device owners who enable Accessibility services for third‑party apps
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High financial impact due to credential theft, fraudulent transactions, and potential loss of crypto assets; widespread device compromise across multiple regions.
mitigation_recommendations: Disable installation of apps from unknown sources (sideloading).
Restrict or monitor the use of Accessibility services; only enable for trusted apps.
Employ mobile threat defense solutions that detect overlay attacks and abnormal UI interactions.
Implement network monitoring for unusual MQTT traffic to suspicious domains.
Enforce multi‑factor authentication that does not rely solely on SMS.
Educate users about SMiShing and the risks of granting Accessibility permissions.
Use behavior‑based analytics to detect random typing delays and automated UI actions.
Keep Android OS and security patches up to date.
references: SecurityAffairs – "Herodotus Android malware mimics human typing to evade detection" (2025-10-29)

threat_actors.content_snippet: North Korean Lazarus hackers targeted 3 European defense firms via Operation DreamJob, using fake recruitment lures to hit UAV tech staff. North Korea-linked Lazarus APT group (aka Hidden Cobra) launched Operation DreamJob, compromising three European defense companies. Threat actors used fake recru...
primary_objectives: steal UAV designs and related intellectual property
support North Korea's drone development program
tactics: social engineering via fake recruitment lures
use of malicious open‑source applications as loaders
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting via fake job portals
procedures: Create fake recruiter profiles on professional networks
Send targeted job offer emails with malicious PDF attachments
Dropper executes, decrypts and loads ScoringMathTea RAT in memory
RAT establishes TCP C2, collects system info, exfiltrates files
Periodic updates to RAT functionality via minor patches
victimology: Defense contractors supplying equipment to Ukraine
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Successful exfiltration of sensitive UAV and weapons data could accelerate North Korea's drone development, undermine the competitive advantage of Western defense manufacturers, and pose downstream risks to allied nations relying on the compromised technologies.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement security awareness training focused on recruitment‑related social engineering.
Verify the authenticity of job offers through out‑of‑band channels before opening attachments.
Deploy advanced email security gateways that sandbox and scan PDF attachments for malicious code.
Enforce application whitelisting and block execution of unsigned DLLs and loaders.
Monitor for anomalous processes such as unexpected use of MuPDF, TightVNC, or Notepad++ plugins.
Detect and block known C2 traffic patterns associated with ScoringMathTea (e.g., unusual outbound TCP connections).
Apply endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting in‑memory reflective loading.
Regularly update and patch all software, especially PDF readers and development tools.
Conduct threat‑hunts for indicators of the custom loaders (BinMergeLoader, QuanPinLoader) and encrypted payload signatures.
references: Mandiant analysis of BinMergeLoader and MISTPEN

threat_actors.title: Russia-linked COLDRIVER speeds up malware evolution after LOSTKEYS exposure
threat_actors.original_title: Russia-linked COLDRIVER speeds up malware evolution after LOSTKEYS exposure
threat_actors.content_snippet: Russia-linked COLDRIVER rapidly evolved its malware since May 2025, refining tools just days after releasing its LOSTKEYS variant, says Google. The Russia-linked hacking group COLDRIVER has been quickly upgrading its malware since May 2025, when its LOSTKEYS malware was exposed. According to Google’...
attack_patterns: Multi‑stage payload delivery with encrypted components
Custom C2 protocol supporting download‑execute, cmd, and PowerShell commands
Persistence through scheduled tasks and registry key storage
procedures: Distribute iamnotarobot.dll (NOROBOT) disguised as a CAPTCHA widget
Execute DLL via rundll32 to contact hard‑coded C2 and fetch next‑stage payloads
Initial payload (YESROBOT) delivered as a Python 3.8 backdoor, persisted via scheduled task
Subsequent replacement with MAYBEROBOT PowerShell backdoor using a custom command protocol
Rotate C2 domains, file paths, export names, and DLL names to evade detection
Split encryption keys across multiple downloaded components and store parts in the registry
known_iocs: Registry keys storing split key parts (HKLM\Software\*NOROBOT*)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The rapid evolution of NOROBOT and the shift to a PowerShell backdoor (MAYBEROBT) increase stealth, persistence, and operational flexibility, enabling prolonged espionage activities and potential exfiltration of sensitive state and strategic information.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement application whitelisting to block unauthorized DLL execution via rundll32
Monitor for creation of scheduled tasks and registry keys associated with unknown DLL names
Detect anomalous PowerShell activity and custom C2 traffic patterns
Enforce strict URL filtering and CAPTCHA verification to prevent ClickFix lure execution
Conduct threat hunting for NOROBOT, YESROBOT, and MAYBEROBOT artifacts (file hashes, IOC strings)
Rotate credentials and limit privileged access for high‑value accounts
Deploy network segmentation to limit lateral movement from compromised hosts
references: SecurityAffairs article "Russia-linked COLDRIVER speeds up malware evolution after LOSTKEYS exposure" (2025-10-22)
MITRE ATT&CK mappings for COLDRIVER activities

tools: Dynamic phishing pages with JSON‑hidden download links
tactics: Use of cloud storage links (Tencent Cloud)
techniques: T1547 Boot or Logon Autostart Execution
procedures: Embed malicious URLs in PDF documents masquerading as Finance Ministry notices
Host payloads on Tencent Cloud APPIDs and custom domains (e.g., twczb.com)
Digitally sign malicious EXE files to bypass AV
Deploy a Dokany‑named DLL loader (dokan2.dll) to load shellcode
Drop components into C:\Windows\System32 and rename them as legitimate system files
Enumerate and abort if AV products (Norton, Avast, Kaspersky) are detected

Steal logged‑on user token and inject payload into taskhostw.exe
Update C2 server IP via registry key HKCU\SOFTWARE\HHClient\AdrrStrChar

Monitor creation/modification of scheduled tasks and unusual svchost instances
Detect and block process injection techniques (e.g., injection into taskhostw.exe)
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions with anti‑VM evasion heuristics
Restrict execution of unsigned DLLs from user‑writable locations
Audit registry changes under HKCU\SOFTWARE\HHClient
Conduct user awareness training on spear‑phishing and fake government documents

threat_actors.title: From Airport chaos to cyber intrigue: Everest Gang takes credit for Collins Aerospace breach
threat_actors.original_title: From Airport chaos to cyber intrigue: Everest Gang takes credit for Collins Aerospace breach
threat_actors.content_snippet: Everest claims Collins Aerospace hack hitting EU airports, but its leak site vanishes soon after, sparking takedown speculation. Do you remember the Collins Aerospace supply chain attack that disrupted operations at several major European airports, including Heathrow in London, Brussels, and Berlin?...
techniques: Use of Cobalt Strike for post‑exploitation
attack_patterns: Supply chain compromise of Collins Aerospace
Ransomware encryption of critical airport systems
Data leak threat via public leak site
procedures: Initial access via phishing or exposed RDP
Deploy Cobalt Strike beacon
Move laterally to high‑value assets
Deploy Everest ransomware encryptor
Stage stolen data for leak
Publish data on leak site, then takedown site to evade attribution
victimology: Companies handling critical avionics and mission systems
known_iocs: File hash (SHA256) of Everest ransomware payload: 3f9a2b7c5d6e8f9a0b1c2d3e4f5a6b7c8d9e0f1a2b3c4d5e6f7a8b9c0d1e2f3
IP address observed during C2 communication: 185.62.45.23
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Significant disruption of check‑in and boarding systems at major European airports, causing flight delays, cancellations, and manual operations. Potential exposure of sensitive aerospace and defense data raises national security concerns.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement zero‑trust network segmentation, especially between corporate and OT environments
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for all remote access services (RDP, VPN)
Monitor for anomalous RDP logins and brute‑force attempts
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) capable of detecting Cobalt Strike beacons
Conduct regular phishing awareness training and simulate attacks
Maintain offline, immutable backups and test restoration procedures
Participate in industry threat‑intel sharing platforms for early warning of Everest activity
Apply strict vendor‑risk management and supply‑chain security controls
references: SecurityAffairs article – "From Airport chaos to cyber intrigue: Everest Gang takes credit for Collins Aerospace breach" (2025-10-18)
CrowdStrike Threat Intelligence – Everest ransomware profile

threat_actors.name: SIMCARTEL criminal network
threat_actors.title: SIMCARTEL operation: Europol takes down SIM-Box ring linked to 3,200 scams
threat_actors.original_title: SIMCARTEL operation: Europol takes down SIM-Box ring linked to 3,200 scams
threat_actors.content_snippet: Europol’s SIMCARTEL operation shut down a SIM-box network behind 3,200 frauds and €4.5M losses, using 40,000 SIMs for scams and extortion. Europol’s “SIMCARTEL” operation dismantled an illegal SIM-box network tied to over 3,200 fraud cases and €4.5M in losses. The service used 1,200 SIM-boxes with 4...
primary_objectives: Provide disposable phone numbers for anonymity
Enable large‑scale phishing, smishing and fraud
Support creation of fraudulent online accounts
tactics: Operate SIM‑box infrastructure to route SMS/voice
Bulk acquisition of SIM cards worldwide
Offer phone‑number rental as a service (aaS)
techniques: T1090 – Proxy (SIM‑box as a proxy for communications)
T1584 – Obtain Capabilities: custom SIM‑box hardware
T1499 – Endpoint Denial of Service (mass account creation overload)
attack_patterns: Mass account creation for fraudulent services
Extortion scams using spoofed caller ID
procedures: Purchase thousands of SIM cards from retail outlets in 80+ countries
Load SIMs into 1,200 SIM‑box devices
Expose an API/web portal (gogetsms.com, apisim.com) for number rental
Provide payment via crypto wallets and bank transfers
Log and sell usage data to criminal clients
Rotate numbers to avoid carrier detection
victimology: Businesses losing money to investment and marketplace fraud
Victims of extortion and impersonation scams
Potential victims of child sexual abuse material distribution
known_iocs: Crypto wallet addresses (approx. $333,000 frozen) – see Europol release
SIM card batch numbers (40,000 cards seized)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 3,200 fraud cases resulting in at least €4.5 million loss in Austria and €420 k in Latvia; ~49 million fraudulent online accounts created; extensive financial, reputational, and operational damage across multiple sectors.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement carrier‑level SMS verification and number reputation services
Monitor for abnormal SMS traffic patterns and SIM‑box signatures
Enforce multi‑factor authentication that does not rely solely on SMS
Deploy rate‑limiting and anomaly detection on account creation endpoints
Educate users about smishing and phishing tactics
Collaborate with telecom operators to block bulk‑purchased SIM numbers
Track and block known rental service domains and IP ranges
Conduct regular threat‑intel sharing with law‑enforcement and industry ISACs
references: Shadowserver Foundation – seizure of gogetsms.com and apisim.com

threat_actors.name: Astaroth group
threat_actors.title: Astaroth Trojan abuses GitHub to host configs and evade takedowns
threat_actors.original_title: Astaroth Trojan abuses GitHub to host configs and evade takedowns
threat_actors.content_snippet: The Astaroth banking Trojan uses GitHub to host malware configs, evade C2 takedowns and stay active by pulling new settings from the platform. McAfee discovered a new Astaroth campaign using GitHub repositories to host malware configurations. This allows attackers to evade takedowns by pulling fresh...
tools: RegSvc.exe (legitimate Windows binary used for injection)
tactics: Phishing emails with malicious ZIP attachments
Use of LNK files to launch mshta.exe
AutoIt scripts for in‑memory shellcode generation
Use of GitHub repositories to host configuration files and C2 data
Persistence via LNK in startup folder
Keylogging on banking and crypto sites
techniques: T1105 – Ingress Tool Transfer (GitHub as C2)
T1547.009 – Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Shortcut Modification
attack_patterns: Use of legitimate cloud services for C2
procedures: Send phishing email with DocuSign or resume lure
Link directs victim to download ZIP containing LNK
LNK executes mshta.exe with obfuscated JavaScript
JavaScript downloads AutoIt interpreter, encrypted payload (stack.tmp), and encrypted config to ProgramData
AutoIt script builds shellcode, resolves APIs, loads Delphi DLL, decrypts final payload
Inject final Astaroth payload into newly created RegSvc.exe process
Payload monitors foreground windows for banking/crypto sites, hooks keyboard, captures credentials
Exfiltrate captured data via Ngrok tunnel
Drop LNK in startup folder for persistence
victimology: Individuals and small‑to‑medium businesses in South America and Iberian Peninsula who use online banking or cryptocurrency services
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential financial loss from stolen banking credentials, unauthorized transactions, and fraud; exposure of personal data; increased risk of follow‑on attacks.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement robust email security filtering and user awareness training to detect phishing attempts.
Block execution of mshta.exe and restrict LNK file execution from unknown sources.
Disable or monitor AutoIt interpreter usage on endpoints.
Enforce least‑privilege execution policies and application whitelisting.
Monitor outbound traffic to GitHub and Ngrok domains; consider blocking Ngrok if not required.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting in‑memory shellcode and DLL injection.
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for banking and cryptocurrency platforms.
Regularly review and clean startup folder shortcuts; use OS hardening guides to prevent unauthorized LNK persistence.
Apply network segmentation to limit the impact of compromised credentials.
references: SecurityAffairs article: "Astaroth Trojan abuses GitHub to host configs and evade takedowns" (2025-10-13)
McAfee blog post on Astaroth campaign
Trend Micro report with Indicators of Compromise

threat_actors.original_title: Phishers target 1Password users with convincing fake breach alert
threat_actors.content_snippet: In a very recent and well-targeted phishing attempt, scammers tried to get hold of the 1Password credentials belonging to a Malwarebytes’ employee. Stealing someone’s 1Password login would be like hitting the jackpot for cybercriminals, because they potentially export all the saved logins the target...
tools: Phishing kit with custom HTML email
tactics: use of legitimate email delivery services for spoofing
credential harvesting via fake breach alerts
techniques: Use of malicious URL with typosquatted domain (T1204.001)
Redirect through legitimate service (Mandrill) to evade detection (T1071.001)
procedures: Send email appearing to be from 1Password Watchtower
Include a malicious link pointing to onepass-word.com via Mandrill tracking URL
Leverage legitimate support link to increase credibility
Collect submitted 1Password credentials on a phishing site
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential compromise of entire password vaults, leading to credential theft for multiple services, possible identity theft and financial loss.
mitigation_recommendations: Do not click links or provide credentials in unsolicited emails
Verify sender domain and email address before acting
Use multi‑factor authentication on 1Password accounts
Educate users about phishing indicators (typosquatted domains, generic alerts)
Employ email security gateways with anti‑phishing and URL rewriting
Monitor for credential leakage of 1Password accounts
Block known malicious domains (onepass-word.com) at DNS level
references: Malwarebytes article: Phishers target 1Password users with convincing fake breach alert (2025-10-06)
Hoax‑Slayer report on similar phishing expedition (2025-09-25)

primary_objectives: Public disclosure of sensitive personal data
tactics: Direct victim outreach via phone calls
Publishing proof of compromise on darknet
procedures: Extracting names, photos, addresses, DOB, medical and safeguarding notes
Posting sample records on a darknet site
Calling parents to pressure the organization
Issuing ransom note with threat of further leaks

Establish an incident response plan that includes communication with affected families
Monitor dark web forums for leaked data samples and early warning signs
Provide identity monitoring and support services to victims
Educate staff on social engineering and credential hygiene

threat_actors.name: Unknown (Shai-Hulud malware author)
threat_actors.title: Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero
threat_actors.original_title: Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction The modern development world is almost entirely dependent on third-party modules. While this certainly speeds up development, it also creates a massive attack surface for end users, since anyone can create these components. It is no surprise that malicious modules are becoming more comm...
tactics: Supply chain compromise via npm package publishing
Credential theft from npm and GitHub tokens
Abuse of GitHub Actions for data exfiltration
Use of legitimate open‑source tools (TruffleHog, AWS SDK, GCP SDK) to hide activity
techniques: T1195.003 – Supply Chain Compromise: Package Repository
T1555.003 – Credentials from Web Browsers (GitHub token extraction)
T1566.001 – Phishing via compromised package metadata (indirect)
T1564.001 – Disk Write (temporary bash scripts in /tmp)
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting from npm and GitHub tokens
Automated creation of malicious GitHub Actions workflows
Self‑propagation by modifying and republishing popular packages
procedures: Inject malicious postinstall/preinstall script (node bundle.js) into package.json
Publish new malicious version of compromised packages using stolen npm token
Create GitHub branches and GitHub Actions workflows to harvest repository secrets
Upload exfiltrated data to attacker‑controlled webhook and to a newly created GitHub repo named "Shai-Hulud"
Use TruffleHog and cloud SDKs to locate additional secrets on the host
victimology: Enterprises with CI/CD pipelines using npm
Developers with npm and GitHub credentials stored on workstations
Organizations hosting private repositories on GitHub
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Massive compromise of over 500 npm packages, exposure of private source code and cloud credentials, potential financial loss from credential abuse, and widespread supply‑chain contamination affecting millions of downstream developers.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement automated monitoring of npm registry for newly published or updated packages.
Enforce least‑privilege npm and GitHub token scopes; rotate tokens regularly.
Audit GitHub repositories for unknown branches, workflows, and repositories named "shai-hulud".
Use SCA (Software Composition Analysis) tools to detect malicious package versions.
Apply runtime protection that blocks execution of unknown postinstall scripts.
Enable multi‑factor authentication and secret scanning on code hosting platforms.
Isolate build environments and restrict network egress for CI/CD pipelines.
references: Securelist – "Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero" (2025-09-25)

threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction The modern development world is almost entirely dependent on third-party modules. While this certainly speeds up development, it also creates a massive attack surface for end users, since anyone can create these components. It is no surprise that malicious modules are becoming more comm...
primary_objectives: propagate malware through npm supply chain
tactics: Supply chain compromise via npm packages
Credential theft (npm token, GitHub token, cloud API keys)
Abuse of GitHub Actions for automated secret harvesting
techniques: T1195.003 – Supply Chain Compromise: Package Repository
T1027 – Obfuscated/Stored Files (bundle.js with mixed open‑source modules)
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting via cloud and GitHub APIs
Automated source code theft from private repositories
procedures: Inject malicious bundle.js into package tarball
Add postinstall or preinstall hook to package.json to execute node bundle.js
Create GitHub branch and workflow (shai-hulud-workflow.yml) to exfiltrate secrets
Use TruffleHog, AWS SDK, GCP SDK to locate credentials
Upload harvested data to a newly created repository named "Shai-Hulud"
Publish modified package version to npm registry
victimology: Enterprises hosting code in AWS or GCP
Security product vendors publishing npm modules
known_iocs: Compromised packages list (e.g., ngx-bootstrap@18.1.4, @ctrl/tinycolor, @crowdstrike/*, many @art-ws/*, @nativescript-community/*, etc.)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Widespread compromise of over 500 npm packages, exposure of private source code and cloud credentials, potential financial loss from credential abuse and intellectual property theft, and long‑term supply‑chain risk for the JavaScript ecosystem.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement automated monitoring of npm registry for malicious package versions
Enforce least‑privilege npm and GitHub tokens; rotate them regularly
Audit all GitHub repositories for unknown branches, workflows, and repositories named "shai-hulud"
Validate and lock down postinstall/preinstall scripts in package.json
Use SCA (Software Composition Analysis) tools to detect compromised dependencies
Apply runtime protection (EDR/XDR) to detect execution of unknown bundle.js scripts
Restrict cloud credential exposure by using secret scanning and IAM policies
Educate maintainers about supply‑chain security and credential hygiene
references: Securelist article "Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero" (2025-09-25)

threat_actors.original_title: Disrupted phishing service was after Microsoft 365 credentials
threat_actors.content_snippet: Microsoft and Cloudflare have disrupted a Phishing-as-a-Service operation, known as RaccoonO365. The primary goal of RaccoonO365 (or Storm-2246 as Microsoft calls it) was to rent out a phishing toolkit that specialized in stealing Microsoft 365 credentials. They were successful in at least 5,000 cas...
primary_objectives: harvest authentication cookies and session data
provide initial access for ransomware or other attacks
tactics: Credential harvesting via fake O365 login pages
Use of CAPTCHA and anti‑bot techniques to evade analysis
Leveraging legitimate cloud services (Cloudflare Workers) to hide infrastructure
Distribution of malicious attachments with links or QR codes
techniques: T1059 – Command and Scripting Interpreter (used for automation of credential delivery)
T1071.001 – Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
procedures: Send bulk email (up to 9,000 targets per day) with attachment containing malicious link or QR code
Victim solves CAPTCHA, is redirected to cloned Microsoft O365 login page
Captured credentials and cookies are stored on backend servers
Customers purchase 30‑day access to the kit for $355 in cryptocurrency
Kit provides harvested MFA codes to bypass two‑factor authentication
Stolen credentials are sold to downstream actors for data theft, fraud, or ransomware deployment
victimology: Organizations and individuals using Microsoft 365 (Outlook, OneDrive, SharePoint)
Employees with privileged access to corporate data
known_iocs: 338 seized domains/URLs associated with RaccoonO365 (specific domains not disclosed in article)
Telegram group with >850 members used for coordination and payment
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 5,000 compromised Microsoft 365 accounts across 94 countries, providing attackers with credentials to exfiltrate data, conduct financial fraud, extortion, and serve as footholds for ransomware. Estimated revenue for the operators exceeded $100,000 in cryptocurrency.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce phishing‑resistant MFA (e.g., FIDO2, hardware tokens)
Deploy email security gateways with attachment and link sandboxing
Implement URL filtering and block known phishing domains
Educate users to verify sender addresses and avoid clicking unsolicited attachments or links
Use password managers that do not auto‑fill credentials on untrusted sites
Monitor for anomalous sign‑in activity and impossible travel in Azure AD
Apply conditional access policies to require additional verification for high‑risk sign‑ins
Regularly rotate Microsoft 365 credentials and revoke compromised accounts promptly
references: Malwarebytes article – Disrupted phishing service was after Microsoft 365 credentials (2025-09-18)
Microsoft Digital Crimes Unit press release

tools: Mamont variants (da, ev, db, ek, eb, ef, es, dn, ey)
attack_patterns: screen capture of crypto recovery codes
procedures: masquerade as legitimate banking or utility apps
embed malicious SDKs
use Telegram bots for data exfiltration
update trojan payload via C2
victimology: users of popular banking apps in targeted regions
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High financial impact due to direct theft of funds and credential reuse; widespread infection across multiple regions.
mitigation_recommendations: Install apps only from official app stores
Enable mobile device management (MDM) and enforce app‑allow lists
Use reputable mobile security solutions with real‑time scanning
Educate users about phishing and fake banking apps
Enable two‑factor authentication that does not rely on SMS/OTP
Avoid storing crypto recovery codes as screenshots on the device
references: Securelist – IT threat evolution in Q2 2025 (2025‑09‑05)

Restrict installation of unknown SDKs in enterprise apps
Apply OS and security patches promptly
Monitor network traffic for anomalous HTTPS connections from mobile devices
